linkTarget.anchoringText: The largest number of giant oil fields with recoverable hydrocarbon volumes larger than 500 MMboe has been discovered in the 1950s-1970s (Bai and Xu 2014) (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Historical discovery of Giant Fields (recoverable hydrocarbon above 500 MMboe) (from Bai and Xu 2014).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical discovery of Giant Fields (recoverable hydrocarbon above 500 MMboe) (from Bai and Xu 2014).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 2 shows the workflow. The workflow aims at continuously reducing the technical uncertainty but also the economic uncertainty. In addition, by applying the learnings, field re-development using EOR is and the capabilities in the organization improved.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Workflow for implementation of EOR methods.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow for implementation of EOR methods.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Production from the 8 TH commenced in 1951 (Fig. 3). Peak oil production of about 2000 m3/d was achieved in 1957. From then onwards, oil production declined. The reservoir pressure fell to about 80 bar in 1960. Water injection was started in 1960 and oil production stabilised. The water cut continuously increased and is currently at 96 %.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Watercut (top panel, blue), oil (green) and liquid (blue) production from the 8 TH, in the bottom panel water injection is shown in blue and the voidage replacement ratio in red.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Watercut (top panel, blue), oil (green) and liquid (blue) production from the 8 TH, in the bottom panel water injection is shown in blue and the voidage replacement ratio in red.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The top structure map of the 8 TH horizon and currently active injection (blue) and production (green) wells and area of the polymer pilot, with the corresponding injectors S 81 and SC 1, are shown in Fig. 4. Prior to the polymer pilot, water was mainly injected north of the field into the aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Top structure of the 8 TH horizon with the polymer pilot area (red square). The green dots indicate currently active production wells and the blue dots injection wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top structure of the 8 TH horizon with the polymer pilot area (red square). The green dots indicate currently active production wells and the blue dots injection wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Results of the micro-model experiments are depicted in Fig. 5 (Buchgraber et al. 2011).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Results of micro-model experiments (a) water injection (b) polymer injection. Polymer injection results in significantly improved sweep efficiency and more but smaller "fingers". The green lines indicate the inlet and outlet channels.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of micro-model experiments (a) water injection (b) polymer injection. Polymer injection results in significantly improved sweep efficiency and more but smaller "fingers". The green lines indicate the inlet and outlet channels.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Polymer rheology experiments and core floods were performed to derive the parameters required for reservoir simulation. Fig. 6 shows experimental and simulated data of a core flood. Injection of 1.1 pore volumes of water was followed by 4 pore volumes of polymer injection. Then, chase water and a second polymer slug was injected. The incremental oil recovery factor of polymer flooding compared with waterflooding was 12 % for a polymer concentration of 1000 ppm. Polymer adsorption was 4.5 mg/100 g rock, the residual resistance factor 1.5, the Inaccessible Pore Volume 0.3 and the in-situ polymer solution viscosity 7.5 cP.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Measured (dots) and simulated (lines) data of a core flood, cumulative oil production (green), polymer mass rate (pink) and tracer rate (black).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured (dots) and simulated (lines) data of a core flood, cumulative oil production (green), polymer mass rate (pink) and tracer rate (black).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil cut, tracer and polymer response of the polymer pilot is shown in Fig. 7. Tracers were injected one week before commencement of polymer solution injection. The breakthroughs of the tracers in the surrounding wells are indicated in Fig. 7. The oil cut of three wells S65, S66 and S95 increased as response on polymer injection and polymers are producedback from the three wells. For S66 and S95, the oil cut increases almost at the same time as polymers could be detected. The oil cut response of S65 was prior to polymers breaking through at the well. The current oil production in the pilot area is the highest since 1978.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Oil cut (green), gross rate (dark blue), polymer (black triangles) and tracer (arrows) response of the polymer pilot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil cut (green), gross rate (dark blue), polymer (black triangles) and tracer (arrows) response of the polymer pilot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Four areas of uncertainties were identified which needed to be addressed by the polymer pilot (Fig. 8)

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Main uncertainty areas addressed by the polymer pilot (1) surface handling and quality of polymer solution (2) polymer injectivity (3) reservoir effects – incremental oil recovery (4) separation of back-produced oil/water/polymer.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Main uncertainty areas addressed by the polymer pilot (1) surface handling and quality of polymer solution (2) polymer injectivity (3) reservoir effects – incremental oil recovery (4) separation of back-produced oil/water/polymer.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A coupled fluid-flow and geomechanical model including shear thinning non-Newtonian polymer rheology in the fractures and visco-elastic polymer rheology in the reservoir was constructed to simulate fracture growth (Zechner et al. 2015). Fig. 9 shows the Bottomhole Pressure match and fracture growth over time.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (a) Simulation results of the Bottomhole Pressure (BHP) and (b) fracture half-length versus time for the polymer pilot SC1 well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Simulation results of the Bottomhole Pressure (BHP) and (b) fracture half-length versus time for the polymer pilot SC1 well.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Simulation results of the Bottomhole Pressure (BHP)
fracture half-length versus time for the polymer pilot SC1 well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Decline Curve Analysis. Plotting the oil/water ratio versus cumulative oil produced shows a characteristic pattern for the water and polymer solution injection (Fig. 10). The 8 TH reservoir was produced by edge water injection. The blue line in Fig. 10 indicates start of injection into the converted S81 well. Following this conversion and water injection, the oil cut was increased. At the same time, the water salinity showed the response of the injected water. After reaching a peak oil/water ratio, the water/oil ratio decreased steeper than in the edge water injection phase.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Decline Curve Analysis for production well S66. The blue line shows the commencement of water injection in S81 and the red line start of polymer injection.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Decline Curve Analysis for production well S66. The blue line shows the commencement of water injection in S81 and the red line start of polymer injection.

linkTarget.anchoringText: 1D Numerical Simulation. Tracers were injected at several times in S81. The tracer data, back produced polymer data and incremental oil recovery were simulated using a simplified numerical model focusing on the higher permeable flow paths. Matching the tracer data lead to a match of the back produced polymer data as well (Fig. 11) (Clemens et al. 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Measured (dots) and simulated (lines) tracer production from S66 (red) and polymer production (green).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured (dots) and simulated (lines) tracer production from S66 (red) and polymer production (green).

linkTarget.anchoringText: 3D Numerical Simulation. Simulations were performed to forecast the production of the polymer pilot. To ensure that the uncertainties were addressed, a workflow history matching multiple equally probable geological models and ensuring maximum diversity of the geological models was used (Chiotoroiu et al. 2016) (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Workflow used to forecast cumulative oil production for the polymer pilot extension. First, multiple geological realisations are generated which are then clustered in Multi-Dimensional-Space followed by assessing the sensitivity of the parameters and clustering. Then, the resulting cluster centroids are history matched by introducing dynamic parameters. Next, incremental oil production is determined for all of the realisations. The incremental production of the realisations is finally used for probabilistic forecasting of cumulative incremental oil production.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow used to forecast cumulative oil production for the polymer pilot extension. First, multiple geological realisations are generated which are then clustered in Multi-Dimensional-Space followed by assessing the sensitivity of the parameters and clustering. Then, the resulting cluster centroids are history matched by introducing dynamic parameters. Next, incremental oil production is determined for all of the realisations. The incremental production of the realisations is finally used for probabilistic forecasting of cumulative incremental oil production.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The methodology took the geological, polymer property, oil, relative permeability uncertainty and extent of the polymer injection induced fractures into account. The results were used for decisions concerning polymer injection duration and to determine the probability distribution for incremental oil production of the well which will be drilled in 2017 (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Forecast of incremental oil production for the planned polymer injection well S445. The diagram in the top left corner indicates the location of the existing injectors S81 and SC1 and the planned well S445.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Forecast of incremental oil production for the planned polymer injection well S445. The diagram in the top left corner indicates the location of the existing injectors S81 and SC1 and the planned well S445.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Upscaling field test of polymer injection to sector or field roll-out needs to take subsurface optimization, full-field economics and the learning curve into account. Key aspects of pilots versus full-field implementation are shown in Fig. 14 and described in more detail below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Differences in pilot and full-field implementation of polymer injection projects.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Differences in pilot and full-field implementation of polymer injection projects.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Polymer injection cost can be split into pattern (injection well with associated producers) dependent and pattern independent costs. For full-field implementation, the number of patterns and resulting required incremental oil production can be calculated. Fig. 15 shows that the required amount of incremental oil reduces sharply with the number of patterns and levels off.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Required incremental oil for NPV 0 plotted for different number of patterns and oil prices. An exchange rate of 1.1 $/€ and on average 1.5 wells / pattern were assumed (e.g. 12 new wells in 8 patterns, 8 injectors and 4 producers).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Required incremental oil for NPV 0 plotted for different number of patterns and oil prices. An exchange rate of 1.1 $/€ and on average 1.5 wells / pattern were assumed (e.g. 12 new wells in 8 patterns, 8 injectors and 4 producers).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 16 shows that a Minimum Economic Number of Patterns (MENP) can be defined for an average incremental cumulative oil production to achieve Net Present Value (NPV) = 0. In addition, a Minimum Robust Number of Patterns (MRNP) can be defined (Sieberer et al. 2016). This number of patterns is reached if an additional pattern does not change the required amount of incremental oil by more than 5 %.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Fig. 16-Concepts of minimum economic number of patterns (MENP) and minimum robust number of patterns (MRNP) for polymer flooding. The MENP was determined for the assumption of 35,000 m3 incremental oil per pattern – see the black dotted line. The minimum robust number of patterns was evaluated for a required stability of ε=0.05 (change . The red, dashed line indicates the lowest possible incremental oil needed for a successful project, which is for the limit Number of Patterns np → ∞.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fig. 16-Concepts of minimum economic number of patterns (MENP) and minimum robust number of patterns (MRNP) for polymer flooding. The MENP was determined for the assumption of 35,000 m3 incremental oil per pattern – see the black dotted line. The minimum robust number of patterns was evaluated for a required stability of ε=0.05 (change . The red, dashed line indicates the lowest possible incremental oil needed for a successful project, which is for the limit Number of Patterns np → ∞.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The concept was applied to various pattern dependent and independent costs. The results are shown in Fig. 17. Projects can be screened for economic viability using this diagram. The dotted black lines refer to an example polymer injection project with pattern independent costs of about 20 mn € and pattern dependent costs of 3 mn €. For such a project, a minimum number of patterns for robustness would be 9 and the associated incremental average cumulative oil production has to be above about 27,000 m3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Number of patterns required to satisfy the stability criterion, given as different colors. The red lines indicate the incremental oil needed for break-even (NPV=0) at an oil price of 75 $/bbl. The green lines show the corresponding Utility Factor (UF = kg polymer injected / incremental oil in bbl). The black lines indicate an example project, with pattern independent costs a = 20.4 mn € and pattern dependent costs p = 2.9 mn €.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Number of patterns required to satisfy the stability criterion, given as different colors. The red lines indicate the incremental oil needed for break-even (NPV=0) at an oil price of 75 $/bbl. The green lines show the corresponding Utility Factor (UF = kg polymer injected / incremental oil in bbl). The black lines indicate an example project, with pattern independent costs a = 20.4 mn € and pattern dependent costs p = 2.9 mn €.
